title: Operators and Expressions
description: Learn about arithmetic, comparison, and logical operators in DWScript

content.introduction:
Operators are the building blocks of expressions in DWScript. They allow you to perform calculations, compare values, and make logical decisions.

In this lesson, you'll learn about different types of operators and how to combine them to create powerful expressions.

### What You'll Learn
- Arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, div, mod)
- Comparison operators (=, <>, <, >, <=, >=)
- Logical operators (and, or, not)
- Operator precedence and parentheses

concepts.title: Arithmetic Operators
concepts.description: Perform mathematical calculations: + (addition), - (subtraction), * (multiplication), / (division), div (integer division), mod (modulus/remainder)

concepts.title: Comparison Operators
concepts.description: Compare values and return true or false: = (equal), <> (not equal), < (less than), > (greater than), <= (less or equal), >= (greater or equal)

concepts.title: Logical Operators
concepts.description: Combine boolean values: and (both true), or (at least one true), not (inverse)

concepts.title: Operator Precedence
concepts.description: Operators are evaluated in a specific order: parentheses first, then *, /, div, mod, then +, -, then comparisons, then logical operators

examples.title: Operator Precedence
examples.description: Understanding the order of operations and using parentheses

exercises.title: Temperature Converter
exercises.description: Write a program that converts a temperature from Celsius to Fahrenheit using the formula: F = C * 9/5 + 32

exercises.title: Age Eligibility Checker
exercises.description: Create a program that checks if a person is eligible to vote (age >= 18) AND has registered (hasRegistered = True). Display the result.
hints: Use the 'and' operator to combine two conditions
Both conditions must be true for the result to be true

exercises.title: Even or Odd
exercises.description: Write a program that determines if a number is even using the modulus operator. A number is even if number mod 2 equals 0.
hints: Use the mod operator to get the remainder
number mod 2 gives 0 for even numbers, 1 for odd
Use the = operator to check if the result equals 0

content.summary:
Great work! You've learned:

- **Arithmetic operators**: +, -, *, /, div, mod for calculations
- **Comparison operators**: =, <>, <, >, <=, >= for comparing values
- **Logical operators**: and, or, not for combining conditions
- **Operator precedence**: The order in which operations are evaluated
- Using parentheses to control evaluation order

Operators are essential tools you'll use constantly in programming!
content.nextSteps: Next, you'll learn about **input and output** - how to get data from the user and create interactive programs. This will make your programs much more dynamic and useful!
